reasons_to_visit.details: Experience Stavanger with significantly fewer tourists than in peak season. Enjoy a more relaxed exploration of the city and its attractions.
Perfect time to explore Stavanger's excellent museums (Petroleum Museum, Maritime Museum, Canning Museum, Art Museum) and enjoy the warmth of cafes and restaurants ('kos').

reasons_to_visit.reason: Potential for Crisp, Clear Winter Days
reasons_to_visit.details: While often wet, February can offer beautiful, crisp winter days with low sun, ideal for atmospheric walks around the city center or along the coast (if conditions allow).
Benefit from potentially lower prices for flights and accommodation compared to peak summer or Christmas seasons.
Witness the city as the locals live it during winter, potentially finding local events or enjoying less crowded public spaces.
Some low-altitude coastal trails or local hills like Dalsnuten might be hikeable, but require careful checking of conditions (ice, mud) and appropriate gear (waterproof, good grip, possibly cleats).

reasons_to_reconsider.reason: Cold, Wet, and Windy Coastal Winter
reasons_to_reconsider.details: February is typically Stavanger's coldest month (average highs ~2°C/36°F, lows below freezing). Expect frequent rain, sleet, potential wet snow, and strong, chilling coastal winds.
Frequent freeze-thaw cycles mean icy sidewalks and roads are highly likely and hazardous. Good grip waterproof footwear is essential; ice cleats ('brodder') strongly recommended.
Although increasing, daylight is still limited (approx. 8-10 hours). Outdoor activities need to be planned within this shorter window.
Preikestolen (Pulpit Rock) and Kjeragbolten are generally considered off-season and unsafe for hiking due to snow, ice, and unpredictable mountain weather.
Many tourist-oriented fjord cruises and specific guided tours may operate on reduced schedules or not at all during the deep off-season.

reasons_to_reconsider.reason: No Guarantee of Snow in the City
reasons_to_reconsider.details: While snow is possible, Stavanger's coastal location means rain and sleet are more common than persistent, picturesque snow cover in the city itself.

weather.precipitation: High chance of precipitation: rain, sleet, wet snow common. Often overcast and damp. Strong winds possible. Icy conditions very likely, especially mornings.
weather.general_tips: Waterproof and windproof outerwear (jacket, trousers) is crucial. Warm layers (wool, fleece), thermal base layers, hat, gloves, scarf are essential. Waterproof boots with excellent grip mandatory. Carry ice cleats.

tourism_level.crowds: Low. One of the quietest times to visit.
tourism_level.pricing: Generally off-season pricing for accommodation and flights. Good value possible.
tourism_level.overall_atmosphere: Quiet winter atmosphere. Focus on indoor activities, museums, cafes. Outdoor exploration requires careful planning and gear.

events_holidays.name: Valentine's Day (Valentinsdagen)
events_holidays.description: Recognized, but not a major public holiday. Some restaurants might offer special menus.
events_holidays.notes: Book restaurants in advance if planning a special meal.

unique_experiences.description: Explore Norway's oil and gas history with interactive exhibits. Ideal for a cold or wet day.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Allow 2-3 hours. Warm and dry inside.

unique_experiences.description: Wander the charming, potentially icy cobblestone streets lined with historic white wooden houses.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Wear boots with excellent grip and consider ice cleats. Best during limited daylight hours. Respect residents.

unique_experiences.activity: Warm Up in a Cozy Cafe
unique_experiences.description: Escape the elements and enjoy a hot drink ('kaffe', 'kakao') and pastry in one of Stavanger's many cafes. Embrace 'kos'.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Look for cafes with comfortable seating and a warm atmosphere.
unique_experiences.best_time: Anytime, especially when needing a break from the cold/wet.

unique_experiences.description: View collections of Norwegian art, including works by Lars Hertervig.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Check opening hours. Requires a short bus ride or longer walk from the city center.

weather.precipitation: Conditions remain similar: cold, damp, windy with frequent rain/sleet/wet snow. Ice remains a significant hazard. Daylight hours increase noticeably towards month's end (~9-10 hours).
weather.general_tips: No change in gear recommendations - stay warm, dry, and prepared for ice. Utilize the slightly longer daylight.

tourism_level.overall_atmosphere: Late winter feel. Slightly more daylight offers better window for potential outdoor walks, but weather remains dominant factor. Focus still largely indoors.

events_holidays.name: Carnival / Fastelavn Period
events_holidays.description: Minor observance in Norway. Look for 'Fastelavnsboller' (sweet buns with cream) in bakeries around this time.
events_holidays.notes: Not a major public event or festival in Stavanger typically.

events_holidays.name: Local School Winter Break ('Vinterferie' - Potential Timing)
events_holidays.date: One week, often late Feb/early Mar (check Rogaland county calendar)
events_holidays.description: May slightly increase local activity at family attractions or indoor venues, but minimal impact on tourism.
events_holidays.notes: City remains generally quiet for tourists.

unique_experiences.description: Discover the history of Stavanger's important sardine canning industry in an authentic old factory.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Interesting insight into local industrial history. Check opening times.
unique_experiences.estimated_cost: Moderate (entry fee, often bundled with Maritime Museum)

unique_experiences.activity: Walk around Mosvatnet or Stokkavatnet Lakes
unique_experiences.description: Enjoy a brisk walk around local lakes, popular with residents for exercise.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Paths are generally paved/gravel but check for icy patches carefully. Dress warmly. Mosvatnet is closer to the center.

unique_experiences.description: Admire Norway's oldest cathedral. Note: Has been undergoing extensive renovation, check if accessible internally.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Even if closed internally, the exterior architecture is notable. Check official website for current renovation status and access.

unique_experiences.where: e.g., near Sola beach or along Hafrsfjord
unique_experiences.description: Experience the raw coastal scenery on a bracing walk, if weather is dry and winds are manageable.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Requires transport (bus/car). Check weather forecast meticulously. Trails can be muddy/icy. Dress extremely well for wind and cold.
unique_experiences.best_time: Dry, calmest possible day during daylight.
